source.raw_text:
The pull-up is a vertical pulling movement primarily targeting the latissimus dorsi (lats), biceps, rhomboids, and traps, with support from deltoids and forearm muscles for grip and stabilization, working to bring the body up towards a bar using shoulder adduction and elbow flexion. Key muscles include the lats (back width), biceps (elbow bending), rhomboids/traps (scapula retraction), and core (stability). [1, 2, 3, 4]  
This video provides a complete overview of the muscles used in a pull-up: 
Muscles Worked (Primary & Secondary) 

• Latissimus Dorsi (Lats): Main muscle for pulling the body up (shoulder extension/adduction). 
• Biceps Brachii: Elbow flexion (bending the elbow). 
• Rhomboids & Traps (Middle/Lower): Scapular retraction (pulling shoulder blades together) and depression. 
• Posterior Deltoids (Rear Shoulders): Assist in shoulder extension. 
• Forearms: Grip strength and wrist stabilization. 
• Core (Abs, Obliques, Erector Spinae): Trunk stability to prevent swinging. [1, 2, 3, 5]  

Movement Pattern: Vertical Pull 

• Action: Pulling the body upwards against gravity. 
• Grip: Pronated (overhand), palms facing away, emphasizing the lats more than a chin-up. 
• Initiation: Starts from a dead hang, engaging the shoulder blades (scapula) first by pulling them down and back. 
• Execution: Pull chest towards the bar, keeping elbows close, then lower with control. [3, 4, 6, 7]  

This video demonstrates the proper technique for performing a pull-up: 
Key Aspects of the Movement 

• Scapular Engagement: Crucial for power and protecting the shoulder joint, initiating the pull before elbow flexion. 
• Grip Variation: Wide grips target upper lats; narrower grips increase biceps involvement. 
• Full Range of Motion: From a full hang to bringing the chest to the bar for maximum muscle activation. [3, 7, 8]  

You can watch this video to learn how to master the pull-up:
